The side of yogurt was a perfect compliment the spice-filled Kati. 

Giving them 4 stars because though the chicken was yummy in all the spices, the white meat was a tad dry. I also had a sample of lamb curry that included gobs of fat only.  They're located right around the corner from my yoga studio so I will definitely be back.
author: Yvonne N.

description:
Congrats Kasa, you are my first mobile review!

This place is awesome, lots of great flavor, cheerful, bright staff - lots of smiles and greetings.  The food tastes great and is very fresh.  I love sthe tyle of plates also, and decor.  Everything here is simple, fresh,  thoughtful and yummers!  Good job Kasa, you have charmed a new diner, and I can't wait to come back!  Good food, good experience.
author: Brandon E.

description:
Kasa: Indian Eatery. That about sums it up: it's Indian, it's an eatery. it's food. Do I have an issue paying $10.95 for a massive thali plate? Nope. I think that's a perfectly reasonable & fair price. Do I have an issue with bland Indian scraped from containers a la the mall food court? Yup. 

Unfortunately, I ventured to Kasa when it first opened and its reviews were stellar. I arrived and was surprised to see the set-up, but figured Yelp wouldn't lead me astray. Should have trusted my gut instinct(s). I ordered the vegetarian special (saag paneer) thali: saag paneer, some additional paneer + peppers, basmarti rice, chutneys, hot sauce, and a roti: sounds decent, yeah? 

The (very nice) girl proceeded to scrape the bottom of the basmarti rice bin, add some watery, oily daal, plop some additional items from 3/4 empty bins, and top the plate with a dismal lookin' roti. I grabbed a mango lassi, thinking something could salvage the meal -- but even this was thin and crazy spiced with a hodge podge mix of chunky cinnamon. 

I *know* it's hard to find good Indian in this hood -- but trust me, this isn't your savior.
author: Lacey B.

description: The Chicken Tikka / Karahi Paneer Kathi Rolls are outstanding - especially for takeout.
author: Venkatesh I.

description:
Kasa has great chicken tikka masala. It is so full of spices that are layered and complex. I ordered it a la carte and had it with rice. It was great!

I ate in at the restaurant and had a pleasant time. Seating is somewhat limited, but many people order carry-out so there didn't seem to be a problem for anyone. 

What could be a negative, but what I enjoyed, was a tv playing a movie that was strangely intriguing and often in Spanish. Not sure what it was, but it made for great conversation trying to piece it together with my husband.

I'll be back to try something new!
author: Meadow P.

description:
Solid home cooked style Indian food, home cooked as in what food at an actual Indian persons home would taste like, trust me i eat at a lot of Indian peoples homes.  Not like most indo-pak restaurants that make Americanized Indo-pak food (shalimar, pakwan, naan 'n'curry etc), Americanized indo-pak can still be tasty, but there's nothing like home cookin'.   Nicely decorated place with lots of windows for people watching, in this neighborhood that's a mixed blessing.   Friendly staff.



Restaurant
author: Sunny J.

description:
Frankly quite disappointing.. Not sure why there are so many positive reviews here. I am a fan of the Kasa in Castro, so maybe I came in with very high expectations. The place definitely has great ambience, located very well etc.. but the food quality was mediocre at best. I ordered a thali as I usually do at the other Kasa.

The * saag paneer was decent (nothing too great),
        * lamb curry was too salty
        * Roti seemed a bit cold, uncooked around some areas
        * Dal was good
        * salad so .. so
        * rest of chutneys were good

Mango lassi was quite bitter (maybe too much cinnamon), which I did get exchanged 

So overall I would say salty food which didn't have any strong flavors. Hope this was just an off day.
author: Anand V.

description: Ordered a thali and the food was not that good. It didn't feel like authentic Indian food. I just didn't like the taste.
author: Kapil D.

description:
Dear Kasa,

Please remove the gorgeous man from behind the counter. He has the potential to severely skew my review. Blame my brown fever. Whatever it is.

As for my Thali Plate, opting for the lamb curry (to avoid the token white person chicken tikka variety - I'll be back for you) and keema mutter, along with all the fixins. Flavors were all delicious, but all was lost as the lamb went from hot to not and the sauce congealed into a fatty mess. It was the most unappealing thing to look at on a plate and my arteries told me no, as if my eyes already didn't. I just couldn't eat anymore of it, albeit tasty. Other than that, delicious, great looking plate for a good price.

Great for solo dining or with friends at the big communal table. Solid, homestyle Indian grub at an accessible price point and atmosphere, eye candy or not.

Request to Kasa: add some hooks under the high tables and bars so people have a place to put their backpacks or bags instead of holding them while they eat.

As for the guy behind the counter...
author: Alissa A.

description: Ordered lam curry kati roll and samosa, love the green sauce that came with the order, but I think the meat is a bit dry. Will try the chicken tikka masala next time.
author: Kylie K.

description: Watch out if you don't like their "food" or they will start sending you nasty notes through yelp. However, they don't have the guts to post their response in public. This place is a joke, and now, the owner appears to be a joke too. Keep up the great work.
author: Andy T.

description: Alright, I would come here again, it's a nice restaurant with good food and a nice staff.
author: Jan S.

description:
I haven't really eaten Indian Food, BUT It was good.

Rice was lovely
Lamb soft and savory
Chicken also soft and spicy
the Cucumber salad and yogurt sauce was delish!

The problem I had was Friday Jan. 3 14 price was $11 and change
and I got the exact same thing Friday Jan.10.14 and it was $17 and change....

WTF is that....scketchy to me...
author: Franziska G.

description: There are few times in life when the meal is so prefecture crafted that it literally blows you socks off. Ha! KASA ROCKS!   try it!
author: Heinz G.

description: Samosas. I feel like for the price, it wasn't such a great deal. It's nice that this place is close to the bar zone though. It definitely hit the spot after a night of imbibing.
author: Ruobin W.

description: I love this place for a reasonably priced Thali!  Great spices - really good.  I lived in India and am very picky - I hit this place regularly!  Only complaint is that the music is too loud.  Other than that, YUM! And friendly staff!:)
author: Kbai F.

description:
Their Castro location was pretty epic, but it was all the way over in far-off Castro.. so I barely got to devour their delicious kathi rolls :'(
But hungry no more!! Kasa has now opened a branch just a couple of blocks away from my apartment :D
Their storefront/ambience/decor are pretty awesome.. and the food is as good as ever!
Like Chipotle, a lot of Kasa's appeal comes from the fact that they make the Kathi roll right in front of you.. watching them take a freshly made roti and stuff it with a yummy subzi and lots of onions and chutneys should make a compelling case for you to forget doing takeaway and gobble up it up then and there!
Beware their spicey green chutney.. its pretty darn spicey... If the line isn't that crazy, maybe try one that is just "mild" and use that to figure out how spicey you want the remaining 19!!!
The Aloo Jeera subzi can get a little too dry, so maybe ask for extra yogurt if you are getting that one. I have had trouble with excessively watery subzis within the kathi roll in the past (from their castro location), so don't throw away the wrapping foil before you start eating!
They have some awesome Indian soft drinks in their freezer including Maaza which is a yummy mango drink I can never get enough of!
A great addition to this neighborhood, hope they are here to stay.
I hope they soon become neighbors to Vik's Chaat Corner's inaugural SF branch!! :D
author: Aditya M.

description: Pay way to much for so little. The naan is a wheat tortilla...or so it looks and tastes. Like the previous review the dahl is mre like lentel soup. Portio s are oh so small...comeon guys!
author: fred h.

description: It does what it says on the tin;))) Clean, spacious Indian street food place. We wanted a light lunch before a long flight home - my 12-yo son had a chicken Kati roll, I had a vegan one. Size-wise it was exactly what we wanted. 2 rolls + chai =$15, in London you would pay about £7-9 in a Kati roll place. I suppose considering prices here $15 was ok;)) I know Indian food well, and this was more than adequate for a street food place. Recommended to eaters on a budget!
author: Tatiana K.

description:
We are out-of-towners missing authentic Indian food & spices in our city. We just now had Vegetarian Kati Rolls & they were very yummy. Spice levels were perfect & the mint chutney gave an awesome kick/punch to the  taste.  

But only 3 stars because we also ordered KIDS ROLL for our 1.5yr old. It was really really TERRIBLE. Plz that's NOT "Indian" & it can never go on an "Indian" food menu. We never ever mix yoghurt + semi-Cooked egg + rice in a roti or a burrito. Yucky taste seriously!
author: Shilpa R.

description: Worst food ever .... who ever gave good reviews must be their own people ...I never visit here again...it is waste of money and time
author: Abc A.

description: My husband and I got suckered in by the "best chai in SF" sign. The chai was sugar with a side of luke warm milk and a splash of chai. Not to mention it was probably made yesterday. I ran to the restroom and when I went to flush the water splashed back all over me. Gross! On the upside the service was great.
author: H K.

description: Good -- if you are familiar with their food truck -- the kati rolls should be familiar. Had the Thali, which is a good deal since you get lots of variety.  The chicken tikka was "so so" since it's pre-made, but saag paneer, keema muttar, gobi aloo was good.  And it's a good value. Interesting drinks.
author: Dan C.

description: Just ordered a Kati roll with Chicken tikka masala from Caviar (this was a special today) and it was the perfect lunch! Delivered seamlessly to my office it was the perfect size for lunch and full of flavor and super fresh ingredients. They gave me extra raita (YAY) and hot sauce upon request. Loved this and will definitely be ordering again or going in to satisfy my tikka craving. Thanks Kasa and Caviar for an easy and delicious lunch!
author: Sarah A.

description:
The chicken tikka tako(my personal name for the Indian cousin of the taco) is probably the best "after-drinks" snack. 
I specially love the cream-yogurt side that comes with each "taco"
author: Leonardo L.

description: I hate writing bad reviews but this was a really disappointing meal. I ordered their chicken tikka masala thali on Caviar. The CTM was WAY too salty, brown (not orange-colored) and tasted more like a Latin American dish than an Indian one (citrusy and lacking the familiar curry flavors we're used to with CTM). I probably would have forgiven the brownish color and Latin flavors if they didn't clearly douse the dish with what must have been an entire cylinder of Morton's salt. Truly inedible. I agree with Deepa: how could they screw up CTM??
author: Kimberly L.

description:
This review is for the kati rolls that we had delivered - kadai paneer and chicken tikka. The two stars are basically for the excellent rotis used for the kati rolls. And my husband liked the green sauce and the yoghurt. Other than that it was not good. 

For starters, there was almost as much rice in the kati rolls as anything else. No no no. Absolutely no rice in kati rolls. Anyone who tells you otherwise has no idea what they are talking about. A gracious point of view would be to think that they were buying into the whole burrito style of things. Though I am more inclined to believe that they are trying to make the rolls bigger without having to use more of the expensive ingredients (eg: chicken, paneer). Not done.

And please don't deliver if you can't at least attempt to deliver food that is supposed to be hot, at the very least lukewarm. How do expect the food to stay hot if it's transported by bike across town in a brown paper bag? Least you can expect with a $7 delivery charge.

Go to Curry Up Now for a much more authentic kati roll.
author: Sanjukta R.

description: A good place to grab something quick that isn't your average boring American fair.  I admit I am no expert on Indian food, and I will say it is a bit different from other Indian food I enjoy - but still very good just the same.    The vegie salad is a must try.
author: Greg B.

description:
When Kasa opened in the Castro, it was our favorite Indian food! They used to make the roti from scratch and everything was fresh. Even the Kasa trucks used to have the home-made roti! Yesterday evening my husband & I went to the Polk St location and I ordered the chicken tikka masala kati roll and he ordered the lamb kati roll; we also had the samosa and the chai. The roti was not the hand-made type that I had had at the Castro location some time back; it was a warmed, pre-packaged tortilla. When I asked the person working behind the counter about the "roti," he said that as long as he had been there they had been using the pre-packaged version.

The worst part is that my husband threw-up last night after having hours of bad indigestion from the food. I didn't feel great, but didn't throw-up. I guess any place can have a problem a single time, so hopefully this was just one of those unusual things.

I am so disappointed to not have the home-made roti (and it still says home-made on the Kasa website). I am also disappointed that I couldn't find a way to contact the owners from their website. Kasa was a great idea and had great execution - maybe it's hard to expand and keep up the level of quality.
author: K S.

description: Indain food but Americanized.My only love goes for the Samosai ( chicken) with chai.Their rolls are great with Dry chicken (tandori) and onions.with lentil soup ... Next to yoga studio and me thinks all yoga come here to do their belly yoga :-)
author: Dannialson N.

description:
Pros: some amazing food here (I would highly recommend the Karahi Paneer), service is super nice, and the price is great for the volume of food you get.

Cons: some of the food is meh (companion didn't care much for the chicken masala or the chicken tikka masala), there's a lot of food on your plate that seems to be there just to fill it up, and what I dislike ultimately, what you see on the menu is what you get. It's essentially a buffet of foods and there's not much they can do in regards to customizing things you want.

That being said, it's not often I would wander out alone to brave the dreaded Polk Street just for food, but I would *happily* do that for the Karahi paneer. That dish is AMAZEBALLS.

In summary, decent food, not my favourite for Indian, but I'd happily go there again.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Unfortunately, the food here was not great. It was cheap which is nice, but there are far better Indian food restaurants in SF. I'd rather pay more to enjoy my Chicken Tikka Masala, Kasa's just did not taste good.
author: Kara S.

description:
I remember when Kasa started on Fillmore St. (where Tacko now resides). It was OK back then. I dropped by the Polk St. branch earlier today and I'm sorry to say that it was abysmal. 

The food? Simplistic, bland, questionable freshness, uneven temperature, poor cuts of rubbery meat, dry rice and rotis, etc. 

The setting? That part of Polk St. is no flower garden but the cleanliness and overall set up of the restaurant is noticeably bad. 

The service? Inoffensive. The guys seemed distant but they did what they had to do. 

Clearly there is no joy in the food, service, and ambience. It's basically for starving students to get something in their belly that has a kick to it. 

All is not lost though. I tried Curry Up Now for the first time last week and it blows Kasa away by a country mile.
author: 1 D.

description:
Bad food, high price structure, the McDonalds of Indian street food. AVOID. I have tried this place, both Polk and Castro locations, a couple of times for lunch. How could anyone take one of the worlds greatest cuisines and dumb it down this bad. Tastes like souless factory food. Frozen?
Either $7 for a small wrap or $12 for a combo plate. Extra $1 for this, $1 for that type of upselling. The place is more about the money formula than the food. You leave feeling like you were pick pocketed.
As for service it all happens at the counter with the food slooped on to divided metal plates. Like dinning in San Quinter. Look elsewhere for your Indian fix.
author: David I.

description: Just a very comfortable place. The food is casual but tasty. It's a real convenient location at the intersection. It's decor is bright and cheery, with the littany of silver Indian tiffins being a nice cultural and artistic touch. It seemed to be a very clean place, so it's not completely a hole in the wall, lol. And to top it off, the owner (I forgot her name) was very warm and friendly. Again, the word comfortable keeps coming to mind.
author: Parvez F.

description: I ordered a chicken tikka masala kati roll and a samosa. Soooo flavorful and delicious! The samosa was pretty big, i loved the chutney sauce, and the size of the kati roll was perfect. I really appreciated the friendly service I received from the gentleman behind the register as well!
author: Cat M.

description: Just had lunch here with my brother, it was OK, but a real daal is made with yellow lentils not black beans.  The food was decent, quick and cheap, but the chai tea was too sweat.
author: pochini m.

description: Tasty kati rolls! Very nice ambience. Chai served with Parle G biscuits brought about a real wave of nostalgia. The poppadum with chutneys is not to be missed.
author: Balakrishnan S.

description: The food tasted fine. The server was very patient and explaned everything well. The soda they serve doesn't have corn syrup. I got pretty significant bleeding in my stool the next day which was the second time in my 35+ years of existence. The food didn't look fresh and based on the consequences, I will not return here again. I would suggest a hygiene and freshness check in all their food and appliances.
author: Emmanuella A.

description: This place was fast and flavorful. We were deliberating whether we wanted a Kati role(an Indian burrito) or a Thali plate(deconstructed burrito with rice). They let us try every item we wanted before deciding on our items. The portions aren't huge so we ordered a couple rolls and plates. Pretty cheap though. We'll definitely keep it in our list of neighborhood joints!
author: NJ A.

description:
Order daal, cucumber salad and two kati rolls

Daal was way too spicy to be edible. 

Cucumber salad was dry and not enough dressing

Ordered aloo gobi rolls - potatoes were large chunks and undercooked.

not worth the $15 we paid, I wouldn't recommend coming here.
author: Mayur K.

description: I was greeted by a nice warm smile and served charcoal dried rock hard chicken Tikka it was hardly edible and kinda expensive they just throw the food on the plate! The chicken tikka masala was ok the spices were nice not much on the plate though maybe 3 pieces of chicken. Had to rush to the bathroom not long after eating there hope I don't get sick! Won't be going back there again that's for sure! The two stars is for the smile and the spices!
author: Pedro D.

description: I've been here about 3 times now for lunch in my neighborhood and really enjoyed it each time. Still have to try their signature Kati roll, but strongly recommend their Thali combo plate - a good amount of food for the price (I think it's about $10-12) and an opportunity to try 2 entree offerings, along with rice, bread, daal and any of the side salads and sauces. Delish. Fresh and flavorful. I don't eat meat but there are at least 2-3 veggie entrees to choose from. Casual dining set-up where you order and get your food at the counter and then grab your own table. Water, napkins, utensils, etc are at a station on the side of the dining room. Restaurant seating is good for solo dining, couples and smaller groups. They do have one longer table down the middle of the dining area, but it's usually shared by said smaller groups and individuals. Haven't been here in the evenings so not sure about the scene. Check it out - better ambiance and quality than Shalimar further down Polk St. (although that place saved my life when I was drunk and starving.) Hopefully Kasa remains the friendlier, classier, quieter alternative.
author: Barbara K.

description: Had the lamb curry and chicken tikka masala Kati rolls. Both were tender and spicy. Pretty good.
author: Jian C.

description: Thali plate has been consistently good and delicious. Recommend the Aloo Jeera, Vegetable of the day or Chicken tikka masala.
author: Ssbk B.

description: The Chipotle of Indian food. It's not great, but will do if you need a quick Indian fix. I had the Gobi Aloo, chicken meatballs, and a samosa. Everything was on the average side, kind of like a trader joes frozen Indian dinner in a way. The samosa was pretty good but doesn't have that hand crafted quality that you will get from a real sit-down Indian restaurant. Would I go back? Only if I wanted a quick Indian food fix.
author: Denny C.

description: I came for the launch and I chose the Tali. Price was written 11.99 the white lady charged me 15.49 when I asked her why are you charging me more then the price you written there . She said I charged you rice surcharge. Hahaha quite funny. The food was no where ready to eat. Bad test. They charge u a lot and the food is so bad and un healthy.
author: Hidayat U.

description:
UH just awful. Over priced slop. I mean my goodness I have never tasted such a bland plate of food, waste of my time, sorry but DO NOT EAT HERE the service is just ok, the food is awful, I will give the airiness of this location one star, it is quite nice, 
but go somewhere else if you want a decent tasty meal. Hands down worst Indian-if thats what were calling indian food these days-EVER.
author: Ann M.

description:
Kasa Indian Eatery represents a new low in dining for me. It's simply the worst Indian food I have ever had in my 52 years on this planet.

Before I get into the reasons why, I'd like to exhaust whatever praise is due. 
The concept of Kasa Indian Eatery is not a bad one. Basically, it's Indian fast food served in a corporate setting, in the same way that Starbucks is a corporate coffee place. (Indian/Pakistani restaurants in San Francisco tend to be low rent and funky, and some people would appreciate a slicker presentation. My guess is that those same people would be delighted to get their food almost instantly, instead of at the merely torrid pace most Indian/Pakistani places whip up their food.)

The creators of Kasa Indian Eatery have done a bang up job on their branding. The Polk street location of Kasa Indian Eatery is bright and airy, with warm tones supplied by wood tables and floors, and some bells hanging from the ceiling. The color scheme and fonts are professional and appealing. The background music is soothing, concept appropriate, and just loud enough to provide a veneer of authentic atmosphere without interfering with conversation. That pretty much exhausts my praise.

Unfortunately, again like Starbucks, all of the creative energy of the owners has gone into either branding or, of paramount importance, the art of extracting the last penny of profit from consumers by providing an appalling product at inflated prices.

Let's start with how ghastly the food is. Kasa Indian Eatery makes their basmati rice in a rice cooker, and they get the results you'd expect. The rice was clumped together and mushy in places and undercooked in others. Supposedly, it was cinnamon scented rice, but there was no cinnamon flavor or scent, or even salt for that matter. The spices in the Saag Paneer tasted raw. The cilantro chutney was harsh and medicinal. I could go on, but all the food my wife and I had was uniformly horrible. My wife remarked that the food tasted institutional, like it was from a hospital or a prison. Just so.

Now, let's talk about value. In all cases, the portions were miniscule (which was a blessing in our case). For ridiculously small amounts of two types of entrée, a teaspoon of chutney, about an eighth cup of rice, and a small ladle of watery dal, the price was $10.95. That's what Kasa Indian Eatery jokingly calls a Thali (plate).
The final insult is the $2.50 charge for an eight ounce cup of admittedly good chai. As anyone who has eaten Indian/Pakistani food in San Francisco knows, the standard is to have chai available for free. It's a gesture of hospitality.
Sadly, the owners of Kasa Indian Eatery have no interest in hospitality, making good food, or serving the community. 

You think I'm exaggerating? Trust me, no one who cared the slightest iota about good food could create dishes this inedible. It speaks volumes about the pure contempt the owners of Kasa Indian Eatery have for their customers. Same goes for their portions and pricing.

Generally speaking, I wish small business owners well, even if they are incompetent. It takes a lot of hard work and moxie to run a small business, and I appreciate that. 

However, in the case of Kasa Indian Eatery, the owners are so transparently venal and predatory, I wish them a swift and painful bankruptcy so a potentially prime restaurant space might be made available for restaurateurs who wish to serve the community while they are making a living.
author: Michael K.

description:
The most DISGUSTING and inedible garbage I have ever had the misfortune of putting in my mouth!!! One bite of the so called "kati roll" and I threw the whole thing in trash (where it belongs). I had ordered their chicken and lamb kati rolls, which the person behind the counter prepared by slopping some curry in a greasy tortilla and wrapping it up. Kati roll is a very popular snack in India where skewered grilled meat (hence the name kati, which means skewer) is rolled inside a tasty paratha with condiments and sauces, and is somewhat similar to gyros. You DON'T PUT CURRIED SLOP in a kati roll. On top of it, the SLOP they put in the kati roll was just plane LARD and had a disgusting smell. I have had Indian food all over the country but had never tasted anything this vile ever! My partner had ordered the 'Thali", she also threw the food in garbage after having only two spoon fulls.

While Indian restaurants in the USA  tend to be mostly mediocre or bad, , "Kasa" takes the cake and is definitely the worst one I have ever been to. San Francisco has its share of very bad Indian restaurants, but "Kasa" beats them all. The food was greasy and horrible tasting and I wonder what kind of cheap and unhealthy stuff they put in it..
author: Joe M.

description: i was excited that this place was opening up, even though there are plenty of Indian restaurants on Polk st, but i was really disappointed once they did. They were out of all the good food when we came by to order (which is understandable because they're new and probably under staffed) but the food we did order ended up tasting really bad. i've had a lot of Indian food and i'm a big fan, but this food did not taste homemade, they're ingredients don't taste fresh at all. It was bland and just overall didnt taste good. the spice palate was just so dull i didnt even finish my plate. I should stick with Shalimar like my instincts tell me.
author: Lena E.

description:
I can see from my first review it's been just under a month since my first visit (and subsequent rave review). Tried it again tonight and to verify my suspicion that it has some work to do I checked reviews here and see I am not alone in thinking this place needs to step it up.
My first meal was a great experience. I was happy with it but I will agree with a lot of others on what they are saying about watered down, greasy and fatty substance (at least with the lamb curry). 
Tonight I had 2 kati rolls - one chicken tikka masala and one the lamb curry. I'm not sure why but they weren't all that tasty. I decided to try another samosa and was disappointed to see (as I pointed out in my first review even though I gave 5 stars) that the samosas are still kept in a tin foil container and mine was lukewarm at best. So, after leaving I had already decided I may not be back and was extremely thankful Shalimar is still close by. 
I hate to be mean and I don't give negative reviews easily, but when I do it is always with the hope that the feedback will lead to positive changes that benefits everyone - the customer and the owner who sells more food. 
As I mentioned in my first review, I've had plenty of food from the Kasa food trucks and I was blown away every time. So, I know it can be done. I'm not sure what it is about this location that seems to have something different going on but they should fix it and fix it soon.
author: Matt H.

description: Simple, awesome, and tasty. This place really has great indian food that makes me not feel like I'm dying of an oil overdose. I'm sure it's not the most healthy place on the planet, but it still tastes not as oily and greasy as a few other indian places I have been to. My recommendation - get the combo plate and split it! Bang for your buck...it's ALOT of food for one person. My one star deduction is because of the mango lassi - I've had better - and they are my favorites - so I tend to judge a little harshly.
author: Melinda S.

description: Kasa never fails me -- I love their food. Super super tasty, fresh, and a great value. I was happy to see the new (to me) location open on Pine & Polk, and I stopped there this evening on my way home. So good. Whatever it is you guys are doing, keep it up!
author: Bowen D.

description: In San Francisco where there are plenty of great indian restaurants Kasa is struggling to keep up. Sure that they have different concept and neat looking cool interiors compare to most Indian restaurant. However this is not the reason most people go to a  Indian or any other ethnic restaurant, people go for delicious food and thats what Kasa Indian missing.
author: Lyra S.

description:
Ugh. Don't go here if you're hungry, you hardly get any food. A platter of gravy and sauces... Minimal rice and two very small sides.
Not to mention, their menu is backwards. When you walk in the menu starts at the cashier "pick one" then you move backwards to pick your other gravy/sides. Maybe they should learn something from chipotle...
author: Maureen Z.

description: The thali option is the best, followed by a samosa and chai combo. Food is good, though not my favorite indian food joint in the Bay Area. Always clean and staff is very friendly and courteous. It's a little overpriced for the quality and flavor.
author: Zeenia I.

description: I'm not a fan of room temp. food. Tried the Thali combo plate today and what should be hot wasn't. Barely warm rice, roti, lamb and grilled chicken. Flavors were just okay. Only upside is you get your food fast since it's already cooked resting on steam tables.
author: Jane F.

description: This place is super yummy -- a MUST TRY. If the roti was a bit fresher, I'd up it to 5 stars (hint hint Kasa owners...).
author: Matthew J M.

description: Love the new location.  Nothing beats 2 CTM Kati Rolls.  Mmmm...  And cherry coke on tap.  Heaven.
author: Val U.

description: Downhome Indian food that you would get at your favorite Aunt's house minus the cheek pinching. What can I say about Kasa that hasn't already been said. Food is great and this is a great new location.
author: Chandini D.

description: Well done Kasa team. Love the decor and the new menu. Food is delicious as always! Score for the Polk/Pine area!!
author: sally b.

description:
I love Indian food.  Kasa not only makes delicious Kati rolls, but their more traditional (by Indian restaurant standards) dishes are ridiculously good.

I've had their black daal a few times.  The minute you take a bite it is incredibly apparent that this is the variety that has been slow cooked, kind of like mom used to make it.  It was a specialty at home, so when you get that kind of quality at a restaurant, especially a fast casual spot like Kasa, it is definitely notable.

Yesterday I was in the mood for Kati rolls (Saturday cheat day!).  I had mine made Unda Style, where the equivalent of a one egg omelet is literally fused to a tava heated roti right on the grill.  I ordered both of mine with chicken tikka, all of the fixings (3 or so fresh chutneys, pickled onions, tamarind sauce).  

I wish I could convey how happy I was after my first bite.  Just an unbelievably flavorful experience.  Totally hit the spot.

There are a ton of Indian options, particularly down near the TL.  Kasa in my opinion provides a better overall experience.  It's quick, it's high quality, and it is significantly lighter.  I could eat Kasa everyday and not worry about clogged arteries...for whatever that's worth!
author: Bobby N.

description: Went to the pre opening last night and Kasa has done it again! Amazing location to compliment the best fresh Indian restaurant in SF. Very clean feel inside and great service by the entire staff. This place is a can't miss if you are looking for a high quality, affordable, quick Indian meal.
author: Alex S.

description:
Was there yesterday for the pre-opening.....

Place was spotless and beautifully decorated.....

Food was fresh and fantastic!

Looking forward to some late night grubbin soon!
author: B P.

description: A unique take on the greasy Indian food I'm used to eating at Naan N Curry.  I don't understand why reviewers are saying it's bland, I experienced a spice overload (in a good way!)  Everything I had was delicious.  The plate is a LOT of food.  If you can finish it you're a champ. Paneer was great, chicken tikka masala was awesome.  Don't go in there with expectations of what Indian food is, they have their own style and I'm into it.
author: miranda b.

description: Very fun environment with great Indian food to top it off! A great way to start your night if looking for a casual, yummy dinner before head out to on Polk.
author: Kelsey H.

description: I'm writing from a vegan perspective.  The Thali plate is available vegan style but my chief concern is that there is rarely a main dish for us.  You can order two add on sides, with the rice and naan bread and a small veggie side.  Usually the side dishes are potatoes of some sort.  So you're basically eating tons of carbs and starch.  The chana masala is the one protein source I have seen, but it is rarely available.  It is my birthday today and chana masala was on the menu and I was looking forward to it, but the server informed me after he was almost done making my plate that it was out.  That was basically the only reason I came in, so imagine my disappointment.  I am pretty sure the samosa he gave me has dairy in it, I can taste it, so I am pretty PO'd.  For $16 I shouldn't have to worry about someone being dishonest to me about my order.  I am not sure if I will come back again although I was a fairly regular customer before.
author: Teresa K.

description: Went to Kasa the other night for chicken tikka masala, it was the worst I've ever had, the sauce was greasy and the chicken reminded me of gristle, uneatable.  Not like their restaurant was on Fillmore.  Very disappointed, will never go back and overpriced.
author: Steven Z.

description: Have to revise my original review after coming here again.  Tried the thali plate and would have to give that 3 stars compared to the kathi roll which deserve 5 stars.  Maybe it had something to do with it being the end of the day but the food wasn't as fresh this time around (particularly the rotis, daal, aloo gobi).
author: Sagar G.

description: I've eaten here several times. I've tried pretty much every thing on the menu. All items are delicious and for the price you get ample amounts of food. The only 2 things that I have noticed in many of the items (lentil and lamb dishes especially) is that the chefs tend to over salt much of their items. Given that many people are more health conscious these days, I wish that they'd not do that. Also, there is no "brown rice" option, but the staff mentioned that it was forthcoming, which is nice to know. Other than that, the staff is very courteous and helpful and the food is very flavourful.
author: Timothy L.

description:
Yelp is bordering on useless at this point b/c it seems to attract people who are only able to speak in hyperbole ("1 star, this is literally the worst thing I've ever put in my mouth!"). But as a longtime fan of Kasa, I feel compelled to try to balance the scales a bit.

Everything I've ordered from Kasa has been good. It's not the cheapest Indian food money can buy, but an unda style kati roll is worth the extra couple dollars you'd pay for a comparable sized dish at a cheaper place. 

And for the sake of not contributing to the hyperbole, I'll give it a realistic 4 stars because, as someone else pointed out, the kati rolls are just a bit too small to order just one, and a bit too big to need two. My only complaint for this restaurant.
author: j d.

description:
I was looking forward to this place opening near by after living in NYC and enjoying Kati Rolls on a regular basis. While the ones in NYC are more "taco size" these ones are quite larger more like a burrito. They aren't the same but pretty decent. I go for the potato one every time. 

I usually stop in for lunch for something quick but for a place that pretty much just needs to serve the food...they are slow! Maybe it's just a lunch thing?
author: Michelle L.

description: So delicious. A fantastic alternative to Subway and other quick meals. I got the chicken tikka masala Kati roll with the cilantro and onion. Amazing. $6.25 in total. Also love the yogurt sauce. Mmmm.
author: A B.

description: Great food but Mgnt needs a change.  We were the in a group and the lady that said she was the manager and said 'we must 'be quite'. We were the only people in the restaurant btw on a Saturday night!. The manager was nicer after a bit but our experience was ruined already with her attitude.
author: Mel R.

description: Great food. Good price. Some of the best chai in the city. I love their green chutney and I have really liked almost all of the dishes I've tried. Turkey and peas, lamb, cauliflower with potatoes, paneer...yum! My favorite thing about it is that the food is very fresh and not too heavy or oily. Awesome!
author: Melanie G.

description:
I like the fact this place does not have pictures with terrorist writing on them or pictures that look like a X-Man movie poster with purple people with 12 arms.  The decoration is tasteful and modern. Also they did not cover up those big windows so the light comes in.
It is awesome to have a place with Thumbs-up and Limca in a bottle.
While the food did taste like it was made with fresh ingredients, it was bland. Indian food is supposed to have a kick. Also the Roti was hard and cold, it tasted like it was made much earlier in the day. Re-heated roti is OK, but nothing is better then one made fresh and served off the pan.
I have visited Kasa on Polk a few times, I can safely say the food is way to salty. The lamb curry was way to salty, and tasted more like Philippine adobo  dish then an Indian curry dish.
For the cost the portions should be bigger. The portions for the Thali are small and the roti rolls are tiny for 4 bucks. 
I would go back again due to the place being clean and they have "thumbs-up", I will make sure to bring my own hot sauce to kick the food up a notch.But  once the place gets dirty, I wont be going back since the food at best is just OK.
author: Bob b.

description: Worst curry I have ever had and over priced for what you get.  Both Nan and Samosa were cold, bland and small in size.  Much better off going to the Pakistani place one block up across California St
author: Alex H.

description: Top-notch food - my office takes-out from there and the lunch table is mobbed when folks hear it's from Kasa
author: Steve W.

description: Wandered in, and glad I did. Staff is patient and friendly. Food is comforting yet at the upper end of my spiciest tolerance. I also realized I was eating my thali (plate) wrong after checking out the next table-- you make a little burrito out of it! Loved the cardamom pods, and the lamb was rich and tasty.
author: Sam B.

description: Oh my!  If you enjoy good Indian food, don't go to Kasa.  The food didn't taste anything like Indian food.  The Chicken Tikka Masala a. Was not cooked in a tandoori oven and b. The Masala (a brownish sauce and not orange) tasted bad.  Aloo Gobi was dry and had zero Indian spices.  They didn't have any naan bread.  It was Clean your own table, by pouring the food into a slop bucket at the counter that was full of flies.  I will not be going back to Kasa. To add insult to injury, I am now going to bed with some Pepto-Bismol!  YACK!
author: Tracy P.

description: yummy, quick.. I got some samosas the other day, their sauces are lovely.. the thali is also yummy
author: Madrone H.

description: Eh... opening up a South Asian restaurant within steps of Shalimar is a risky move. Indian food is never going to be super-healthy, so if you're going to indulge, might as well go with the best. I wanted to be fair to Kasa, but I just can't see myself going here again if I'm craving some palak paneer. I like the idea of a kati roll, but in reality, it's a huge pain to eat, really messy; one is not enough but two is too much (doesn't make for good leftovers either). Glad I tried it, but I probably won't come back for the food, maybe to try some mango ice cream.
author: sar h.

description: There's nothing better than spending a (very rare) warm San Francisco weekday evening drinking along Polk st. What made this night even better? Coming across Kasa! We unfortunately showed up a few minutes after close so we couldn't actually try a variety of the food there, but the staff was very kind and even gave us a free end of the day samosa. This place is all right in my book - can't wait to go back and actually try more!
author: Lauren M.

description: Seeing that there are lots of good eats in the area, and have heard good things about this establishment, I was excited to try this place on Polk street. I have a favorite place already (Darbar), but of course I have to try other kinds of Indian restaurants, as everywhere is different. I ordered the Thali platter with Chicken Tikka Masala and Karahi Paneer. These were good, a bit salty, but not bad. I think for the value it's a good size portion. I like the space and the gentleman behind the counter was very nice. This is definitely a different style of Indian food. I'm not exactly sure if it's more Southern India, as with the other restaurants I like are more Pakistani/Northern Indian flavors. The flavors are light, the ingredients were fresh, and I didn't get that heavy feeling walking out of there. The mango lassi was actually quite tasty. It has different spices, a little tart, and not as sweet as the other mango lassis I have had. What I think would make this place better is cooking the food to order. I think it can be almost criminal to have food just sit out there waiting for people to eat it. I think the ingredients are too good to just sit, dry out, and not be as hot as it should be. The Roti became a bit tough, because it seems like they just make batches of it, and just keep it in a warmer. As with the food, the roti would be much better if it weren't sitting out. All in all, it wasn't bad. The flavors are light, ingredients are fresh, and the chutneys they serve balance out the main dishes.
author: Nadia M.

description: Awesome fast food Indian place! I did not expect the authentic flavors this place provided. And it's fairly reasonably priced and clean.
author: Shruti S.

description: OK I have been to all the so called good Indian places in SF.  They were all nasty.  But Kasa was delicious!  I had the Aloo Gobi, the paneer and the roti!  Very fresh, flavorful, nice portions, good prices!  I will come back!
author: John K.

description: food was good but the staff member was on the phone while he prepped our food which was rude and unsanitary !
author: Amy Nicole W.
